_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Randolph Fertilizer Co.
Contact: Dennis Bartley
Phone:  712-625-3111

Facility Policy  

Randolph Fertilizer Co., has an active Training program with all employees. The facility has coordinated with Local Emergency Personnel in event of accidental release and comply with CFR 1910.38. 
If an accidental  release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Fremont County LEPC, and or any other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the envirnoment.

Facility Information
                                                                                                                 
Randolph Fertilizer Co., 109 Depot Street, Randolph, IA has 2   12,000 gallon tanks which are used for the storage of Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3).  The primary activity of our facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers.  The maximum quantitiy stored would be 299,250 pounds in storage tanks and nurse tanks.                                

Worse-Case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario

The worse case scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank released as a gas over a period of 10 minutes. The maximum quantitiy released would be 52,250 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the end point is 2.6 miles.  Randolph Fertilizer Co., has all excess flow devices, Emergency Shut off valves and breakaway valves in place, required by th ANSI Standards and State Requirements.  These will help limit exposure in a release situation.                                                                                                                                                               

The alternate release scenario, a 3 inch trasfer hose is used as an alternate release scenario followed by release  of ammonia for a 2 minutes before an automatic excess flow shut-down valve intervenes or remote m

anual shut-off is closed and stops the flow of ammonia.  The maximum quantity released would be 3,563 pounds.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .4 miles.  The most likely potential incident, would be a release from break in a 1 inch transfer hose release scenario followed by release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic excess shutt down valve(s) intervenes or remote manual shutt off is closed and stops the flow of ammonia.  the maximum quantity released would be 3563 pounds.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm is .4 miles).
 
Accidental Release Prevention Program

General release prevention is covered in Employee training and all employees are aware of companies emergency action plan.  The facility is in compliance with the provisions of "Safety requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, k-61.1", published by The American National Standard Institute, Inc. (ANSI) , and the standards of the U.S.   Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111,  "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The ANSI standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Administrative Code Part 21 - Chapter 43 - Rule 43.6 (200), "standard for the storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".   The OSHA standard id referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see section 8.3 (b).                                                                                                                                                    

Five Year Accident History

No accidental release has taken place in the last five years with offsite exposure.  The facility has ongoing safety updates when the need arises.                                                                          

Emergency Action Plan

The company complies with CFR1910.38 Emergency Action plan and is included in County Emergency Response Plan.  The company provides state and local authorities with Sara Title III and Community Right

to Know and Emergency Planning with the required information.  Randolph Fertilizer Co., keeps a continuous Saftey Program in place, any updates are added to training agenda and are in implemented company wide.
